snippet: Experts in lethal-injection law said some states were reluctant to turn to the drug in part because of its involvement in high-profile executions last year in Oklahoma, Ohio and Arizona in which prisoners appeared to suffer.
abstract: States like Texas, Ohio, Georgia and Idaho seem to have no plans of using lethal injection sedative midazolam in executions, despite Supreme Court's upholding use of drug in capital punishment; reluctance to use drug seems to stem from high-profile botched executions, despite fact that death-penalty states are still scrambling to secure limited supplies of other execution drugs.
lead_paragraph: Experts in lethal-injection law said some states were reluctant to turn to the drug in part because of its involvement in high-profile executions last year in Oklahoma, Ohio and Arizona in which prisoners appeared to suffer.

headline.main: States Snub Execution Drug Approved by Supreme Court
headline.print_headline: States Snub the Drug Approved for Deaths
